research_topic_title: Four Converging Models Explaining Complete Celiac Seronegativity (IgA-tTG2 <1 AND DGP-IgG <1)
executive_summary: Complete seronegativity in biopsy-confirmed celiac disease (all serology <1 U/mL) is best explained by four converging models, organized around two mechanistic hubs. Model A (reduced antigen-specific antibody production): DQ8-restricted epitope repertoire (3-6 vs 14-17 for DQ2.5) compounded by IgG1 deficiency impairing sequential IgM→IgG1→IgA class switching. Model B (wrong antigen): DGP test peptide (PLQPEQPFP) has zero sequence homology with the immunodominant DQ8-α-I epitope. Model C (mucosal sequestration): tissue TG2 traps locally produced antibodies before they reach serum (Salmi 2006: 100% mucosal deposits in seronegative CD). Model D (wrong proxy variable): guidelines use serum total IgA to validate IgA-based serology, but the reference patient has normal serum IgA with fecal secretory IgA below the commercial laboratory's measurement range — proving that serum IgA is not a valid proxy for mucosal IgA production capacity, which is where anti-tTG2 IgA originates. Critically, these four models are NOT independent: IgG1 deficiency is the shared hub connecting A and D (impaired sequential switching reduces both antigen-specific AND total mucosal IgA), while DQ8 genotype is the hub connecting A and B. Three testable markers — IgG1 subclass, fecal secretory IgA, and full HLA-DQ typing — can identify patients at risk for all four failure modes, yet none are in any diagnostic guideline.

key_findings.finding: DQ8 restricts only 3-6 well-characterized gluten T-cell epitopes versus 14-17 for DQ2.5, a 3-5x disparity in antigenic repertoire. DQ8 epitopes derive from protease-sensitive gliadin regions with limited bioavailability, require two-site deamidation (P1 and P9) versus single for DQ2.5, and elicit polyspecific T-cell responses distributed across minor determinants rather than focused immunodominant responses. DQ2.5 forms more stable peptide-MHC complexes (Fallang 2009). DQ2 homozygosity confers OR 96.9 for tTG-IgA positivity. This quantitative T-cell help deficit translates to an estimated 50-70% reduction in baseline antibody production for DQ8-only patients.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: 50-70% reduction in baseline serological signal attributable to DQ8 vs DQ2.5
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All DQ8-only celiac patients (~5-10% of diagnosed CD)

key_findings.finding: IgG1 dominates the anti-tTG IgG response in celiac disease (Comerford 2015), with IgG1 anti-tTG positivity in 56.6% of symptomatic celiacs vs 18.2% silent CD (Agardh 2005). Anti-gliadin IgG is IgG1/IgG3-dominant (Uhde 2020). In a patient with mild IgG1 deficiency (~35-40% of reference midpoint), the dominant subclass of ALL IgG-based celiac backup tests (tTG-IgG, DGP-IgG) is severely depleted, rendering IgG backup testing unreliable. This represents a mechanism entirely independent of HLA genotype.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: mild IgG1 deficiency (~35-40% of reference midpoint) → estimated 60-65% reduction in anti-DGP IgG and anti-tTG IgG signal
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Celiac patients with IgG1 subclass deficiency (prevalence in CD unknown, general population ~2-4%)

key_findings.finding: Siniscalco et al. (Immunity, 2025) demonstrated gut mucosal IgA is generated through sequential class switching IgM→IgG1→IgA, with definitive molecular proof from Sγ1 switch region remnants in IgA plasma cell Sμ-Sα junctions. IgG1 deficiency would bottleneck this pathway, preferentially impairing T-cell-dependent, affinity-matured mucosal IgA — precisely the type needed for anti-tTG2 autoantibody production. Analogous to established IgM→IgG1→IgE pathway where IgG1 deficiency prevents high-affinity IgE generation (He 2013). The reference patient's fecal secretory IgA is below the laboratory's lower limit of quantification (<280 µg/mL, reported as unquantifiable; reference range 510-2040), while serum IgA is normal. This is not merely 'low' — it is unmeasurably low, meaning the true value could be far below 280. This profound dissociation between normal systemic IgA and unquantifiable mucosal IgA is consistent with selectively impaired antigen-driven mucosal IgA production via the sequential switching pathway.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: Estimated 30-50% reduction in antigen-specific mucosal IgA from impaired sequential switching
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Patients with IgG1 subclass deficiency, regardless of HLA genotype

key_findings.finding: The DGP test peptide (PLQPEQPFP, Schwertz 2004) has ZERO sequence homology with the immunodominant DQ8-α-I epitope (EGSFQPSQE). The DQ8-γ-I epitope (EQPQQPFPE) shares only a partial PFP triplet overlap with the test peptide but is a minor epitope. Zhou 2022 confirmed QPEQPFP as the dominant B-cell epitope but studied predominantly DQ2.5 cohorts. DQ2.2-specific unique epitopes exist (Bodd 2012: PFSEQEQPV). No equivalent systematic epitope discovery has been performed for DQ8-only patients' B-cell antibody specificities — representing the largest gap in celiac serology research. NOTE: Zhou 2022 claimed HLA-independent recognition; while their DQ8 subgroup was small, the burden of proof for epitope mismatch remains on this hypothesis. Downgraded from moderate to weak per peer review (Grok 3.12).
key_findings.affected_patient_population: DQ8-only celiac patients whose B cells may target different deamidated gliadin epitopes than the test measures

key_findings.finding: Salmi 2006 (n=177) demonstrated 100% of IgA-competent, serum EMA-negative celiac patients had gluten-dependent mucosal TG2-IgA deposits. Korponay-Szabó 2004 showed deposits appear BEFORE seroconversion, establishing compartmentalized production as the default first step. Serum detection requires a separate pathway: gut B-cell activation → precursor migration to bone marrow → monomeric IgA secretion. Iversen 2017 found NO correlation between gut plasma cell numbers and serum antibody levels, confirming these are independent processes. Tissue TG2 acts as antibody sink (Stamnaes 2016: TG2 binds fibronectin + collagen VI, creating abundant immobilized antigen).
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: 100% mucosal deposit sensitivity in seronegative adult CD
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All seronegative celiac patients with normal total IgA

key_findings.finding: The pIgR paradox resolves the debate between Model A (reduced production) and Model C (compartmentalization): In pIgR-knockout mice (Shimada 1999), reduced pIgR causes INCREASED serum IgA because dimeric IgA backs up into circulation. Therefore, Marsh 3A villous atrophy reducing pIgR expression should increase, not decrease, serum IgA detection. This argues AGAINST pure compartmentalization as explanation for seronegativity and FAVORS genuinely reduced production (Model A) as the dominant mechanism. Compartmentalization provides the final margin below detection threshold only because production is already very low.
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Theoretical framework applicable to all seronegative CD patients with villous atrophy

key_findings.finding: The convergent multiplicative model: For the reference patient (DQ8, IgG1 deficient, Marsh 3A), if a typical DQ2.5 Marsh 3A patient produces ~50 U/mL tTG-IgA, DQ8 alone reduces to ~15-25 U/mL; IgG1-impaired sequential switching further reduces to ~8-15 U/mL; tissue TG2 sequestration consumes substantial fraction before bone marrow seeding; final serum level plausibly <1 U/mL. For DGP-IgG: IgG1 deficiency reduces dominant subclass by ~60-65% AND DGP test peptide has zero homology with immunodominant DQ8 epitope. This model distinguishes 'completely undetectable' (<1) from 'low positive' (1-3x ULN) as mechanistically different populations requiring different explanations.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: Multiplicative reduction: 0.3-0.5 (DQ8) × 0.5-0.7 (IgG1 switching) × tissue sequestration margin = <2% of DQ2.5 baseline, below detection threshold
key_citations: Novel synthesis — no single study models all three pathways
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Patients with DQ8 + IgG1 deficiency + Marsh 3A (reference patient profile); broader relevance to any patient with ≥2 concurrent serological reduction mechanisms

key_findings.finding: Hietikko 2018 quantified TG2-specific plasma cells across celiac disease stages: 79% of pre-atrophy patients (median 2.3% of mucosal plasma cells) and 100% of active CD (median 4.3%). Correlation between plasma cell frequency and serum titers was rS=0.69, while correlation with deposit intensity was only rS=0.43. This moderate correlation means the relationship between mucosal production and serum detection is not deterministic — substantial interindividual variation exists in spillover efficiency, consistent with multiple modifying factors (HLA genotype, Ig subclass status, tissue TG2 binding capacity) creating a wide range of serum outcomes from similar mucosal production levels.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: rS=0.69 correlation between mucosal plasma cells and serum titers; rS=0.43 with deposit intensity
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All celiac patients — demonstrates serum serology is an imperfect proxy for mucosal immunological activity

key_findings.finding: MODEL D — WRONG PROXY VARIABLE: Diagnostic guidelines use serum total IgA to determine if IgA-based celiac serology is valid. The implicit assumption is that normal serum IgA guarantees adequate mucosal IgA production. The reference patient disproves this: serum IgA is normal but fecal secretory IgA is below the laboratory's lower limit of quantification (<280 µg/mL, unquantifiable; reference 510-2040). O'Mahony 1991 established that serum and secretory IgA are under independent regulatory control. Anti-tTG2 IgA originates in the intestinal lamina propria (Di Niro 2012: TG2-specific plasma cells = ~10% of all mucosal IgA-secreting cells), not in blood. Therefore serum IgA level is irrelevant to whether adequate mucosal anti-tTG2 IgA can be produced and spill over into circulation. The combination of normal serum IgA + unmeasurable secretory IgA is MASKED by current guidelines: the algorithm checks serum IgA → finds it normal → concludes IgA-based serology is reliable → reports negative tTG-IgA as 'true negative'. No guideline recommends checking secretory IgA or any mucosal IgA proxy before trusting IgA-based serology.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: Serum IgA normal (within reference range) vs fecal secretory IgA below quantification limit (<280 µg/mL, reference 510-2040) — complete dissociation between systemic and mucosal IgA
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Any celiac patient with normal serum IgA but impaired mucosal IgA secretion — prevalence unknown because fecal secretory IgA is never measured in CD workup

key_findings.finding: THE FOUR MODELS ARE NOT INDEPENDENT — they organize around two mechanistic hubs with shared markers. HUB 1: IgG1 DEFICIENCY connects Model A (impaired sequential IgM→IgG1→IgA switching reduces antigen-specific anti-tTG2 IgA production) and Model D (same impaired switching reduces total mucosal IgA production, causing unmeasurable fecal secretory IgA despite normal serum IgA). One marker — IgG1 subclass level — predicts failure via both pathways. HUB 2: DQ8 GENOTYPE connects Model A (fewer T-cell epitopes → reduced T-B collaboration → lower antibody quantities) and Model B (different immunodominant epitopes → antibodies against targets the DGP test doesn't measure). One marker — full HLA-DQ typing — predicts failure via both pathways. Model C (tissue sequestration) provides the final margin, confirmed by mucosal TG2-IgA deposits. DIAGNOSTIC IMPLICATION: A panel of just three tests not in any guideline — (1) IgG subclass levels, (2) fecal secretory IgA, (3) full HLA-DQ allele typing — would identify patients at risk for all four models. A fourth test — mucosal TG2-IgA immunofluorescence on frozen biopsy — confirms active compartmentalized autoimmunity when all serum tests fail.
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Patients with ≥2 concurrent serological failure mechanisms, identifiable by a simple 3-test panel (IgG subclass, fecal sIgA, full HLA-DQ) that no guideline recommends

biases_documented.bias_type: DQ2.5-centric epitope calibration of DGP assays
biases_documented.description: Commercial DGP tests use peptides (PLQPEQPFP) derived from DQ2.5-immunodominant gluten epitopes. B-cell epitope mapping (Zhou 2022) was performed predominantly in DQ2.5 cohorts. DQ8-only patients may produce antibodies against different deamidated gliadin sequences (DQ8-α-I: EGSFQPSQE, zero homology with test peptide) that commercial assays do not detect. No systematic DQ8-specific B-cell epitope discovery has been performed.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: Unknown — could explain a substantial fraction of DQ8-specific false negatives. The immunodominant DQ8-α-I epitope has 0% sequence identity with the DGP test peptide.

biases_documented.description: Commercial anti-tTG IgG and anti-DGP IgG assays measure total IgG reactivity without reporting subclass composition. Since IgG1 dominates anti-tTG IgG (Comerford 2015) and anti-gliadin IgG (Uhde 2020), patients with selective IgG1 deficiency will produce false-negative IgG results even when other IgG subclasses are normal. Guidelines recommend IgG-based testing as 'backup' for IgA-deficient patients without considering IgG subclass deficiency.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: IgG1 deficiency prevalence 2-4% in general population; if similar or enriched in CD, represents a defined population where ALL IgG backup tests fail systematically

biases_documented.description: Clinical practice and research studies classify patients as 'seropositive' or 'seronegative' without distinguishing between 'completely undetectable' (<1 U/mL) and 'low positive below cutoff' (1-3x ULN). These likely represent mechanistically different populations: the former may have genuinely impaired antibody production (multiple concurrent failure mechanisms), while the latter may simply be near-threshold with a single reduction factor. Lumping them obscures the distinct pathophysiology and required interventions.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: No study has stratified seronegative CD by absolute titer levels (<1 vs 1-cutoff) — the distinction is completely unstudied
evidence_sources: Novel observation from convergent model analysis

biases_documented.bias_type: Serum total IgA as proxy for mucosal IgA production capacity
biases_documented.description: All diagnostic guidelines check serum total IgA to validate IgA-based celiac serology. The implicit assumption is: normal serum IgA → adequate mucosal IgA → IgA-tTG2 test is reliable. But serum IgA and secretory IgA are independently regulated (O'Mahony 1991). Serum monomeric IgA is produced primarily by bone marrow plasma cells, while mucosal dimeric IgA is produced by lamina propria plasma cells via a different pathway (including sequential IgG1→IgA switching in Peyer's patches). A patient can have normal serum IgA but functionally absent mucosal IgA secretion — as demonstrated by the reference patient (serum IgA normal, fecal secretory IgA below laboratory quantification limit). In this scenario, the guideline algorithm declares IgA-based serology 'valid' when the mucosal IgA compartment that actually generates anti-tTG2 is non-functional. This is not a rare edge case — the prevalence of this dissociation in the general population or in CD patients is completely unknown because fecal secretory IgA is never measured.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: Unknown — no study has measured the prevalence of normal serum IgA with depleted secretory IgA in any population. Could affect a substantial fraction of seronegative CD patients.

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: DGP test peptides are equally sensitive across all HLA-DQ genotypes
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: DQ8-α-I immunodominant epitope (EGSFQPSQE) has zero sequence homology with DGP test peptide (PLQPEQPFP). DQ2.2 has unique epitopes (Bodd 2012: PFSEQEQPV). Different HLA molecules present different gluten peptides, driving different B-cell epitope specificities. Zhou 2022 B-cell epitope mapping was predominantly in DQ2.5 cohorts.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: Zhou 2022 claimed recognition was 'irrespective of HLA-DQ allotype' but DQ8-only patients were a tiny fraction. Simon-Vecsei 2012 showed anti-tTG2 converges on a single conformational epitope (Glu153/Glu154, Arg19) that should be HLA-independent — but this applies to tTG2 not DGP assays.
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: If DGP-IgG has reduced sensitivity for DQ8 patients, the IgG 'backup' test for IgA-deficient patients becomes doubly unreliable in DQ8 carriers

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: IgG-based celiac tests are adequate backup when IgA tests fail
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: IgG1 dominates celiac IgG responses (Comerford 2015, Uhde 2020). IgG1 subclass deficiency (prevalence 2-4%) renders the entire IgG backup strategy unreliable. Sequential switching (Siniscalco 2025) means IgG1 deficiency also impairs downstream IgA production — creating concurrent failure of BOTH IgA and IgG pathways.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: In typical patients with normal IgG subclasses, DGP-IgG performs reasonably well as backup
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: Patients with IgG1 deficiency fall through ALL serological safety nets — IgA tests fail due to impaired sequential switching, IgG tests fail due to subclass deficiency

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: Seronegative celiac disease can be explained by a single mechanism
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Values <1 (completely undetectable) cannot be explained by any single 50-70% reduction mechanism — they require multiplicative convergence of 2-3+ independent factors. The reference patient has at least 3 concurrent mechanisms (DQ8, IgG1 deficiency, mucosal compartmentalization).
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: Some SNCD patients may have simpler explanations (total IgA deficiency, immunosuppressive medication, recent GFD initiation)
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: Guideline algorithms assume seronegativity has a single testable cause (usually IgA deficiency) — the multiplicative model implies some patients have no single identifiable cause but multiple partial causes

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: Mucosal TG2-IgA deposits are equivalent across all HLA genotypes
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: No study has quantified deposit intensity specifically in DQ8-only vs DQ2.5 patients. If DQ8 generates fewer T-cell epitopes → less T-B help → fewer TG2-specific plasma cells → lower deposit intensity, then even this 'gold standard' for SNCD may have reduced sensitivity in DQ8 patients.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: Salmi 2006 reported 100% sensitivity in all seronegative adults, but HLA genotype distribution was not reported
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: If mucosal deposits are also weaker in DQ8 patients, even this last diagnostic fallback may fail for the most invisible patient subgroup

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: Normal serum total IgA guarantees adequate mucosal IgA production for reliable IgA-based celiac serology
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Serum IgA and secretory IgA are under independent regulatory control (O'Mahony 1991). Serum monomeric IgA is produced by bone marrow plasma cells; mucosal dimeric IgA by lamina propria plasma cells via different pathways including sequential IgG1→IgA switching (Siniscalco 2025). The reference patient has normal serum IgA but fecal secretory IgA below the commercial laboratory's measurement range (<280 µg/mL, unquantifiable), proving complete dissociation. Anti-tTG2 IgA originates in mucosa (Di Niro 2012), not blood — so serum IgA level is irrelevant to whether the mucosal compartment can produce detectable celiac antibodies.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: In most individuals, serum and mucosal IgA are broadly correlated. Total IgA deficiency (<0.07 g/L) does predict both serum and mucosal IgA failure. The dissociation may be uncommon in the general population.
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: Every diagnostic guideline worldwide uses serum total IgA as the gatekeeper for trusting IgA-based serology. If this proxy is invalid in a subset of patients — those with normal systemic but impaired mucosal IgA — then their negative tTG-IgA is falsely reassuring. The guideline explicitly declares serology 'valid' in exactly the patients where it is most likely to fail. The prevalence of this dissociation is unknown because fecal secretory IgA is never measured in CD workup.

overlooked_populations.population: DQ8-only celiac patients with concurrent IgG1 subclass deficiency
overlooked_populations.estimated_size: Unknown — DQ8-only is ~5-10% of CD, IgG1 deficiency ~2-4% general population. If independent, ~0.1-0.4% of CD patients. If co-enriched, possibly higher.
overlooked_populations.why_missed: DQ8 reduces baseline antibody production; IgG1 deficiency impairs both IgG backup tests AND sequential switching to IgA; tissue sequestration consumes remainder. All three arms of serological testing fail simultaneously. No guideline considers IgG subclass testing in CD workup.
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: IgG subclass testing should be performed in any seronegative patient with suspected CD, especially DQ8 carriers. If IgG1 is low, acknowledge that ALL serological tests (IgA and IgG-based) are unreliable and proceed directly to biopsy-based diagnosis with mucosal TG2-IgA deposit testing.

overlooked_populations.population: Celiac patients with 'completely undetectable' serology (<1 U/mL) vs 'low positive below cutoff'
overlooked_populations.estimated_size: Unknown — no study distinguishes these subgroups within seronegative CD
overlooked_populations.why_missed: Binary seropositive/seronegative classification obscures the distinction. Patients with values <1 likely have fundamentally different mechanisms (multiplicative production failure) than patients with values just below cutoff (single partial reduction).
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: Studies should report absolute serological values, not just positive/negative. Seronegative CD cohorts should be stratified by titer level to identify mechanistically distinct subgroups.

overlooked_populations.population: Celiac patients whose anti-DGP antibodies target DQ8-specific gliadin epitopes not captured by commercial tests
overlooked_populations.estimated_size: Unknown — potentially all DQ8-only CD patients with preserved antibody production who test DGP-negative due to epitope mismatch
overlooked_populations.why_missed: DGP test peptide (PLQPEQPFP) derived from DQ2.5-immunodominant epitopes. No commercial test uses DQ8-α-I-derived peptides.
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: Develop and validate DQ8-specific DGP test peptides (e.g., based on EGSFQPSQE and related sequences). Test seronegative DQ8 patients with expanded peptide panel. If positive, this would prove Model B and necessitate HLA-stratified serological testing.

overlooked_populations.population: Celiac patients with normal serum total IgA but depleted mucosal/secretory IgA (serum-mucosal IgA dissociation)
overlooked_populations.estimated_size: Completely unknown — fecal secretory IgA has never been measured as part of celiac diagnostic workup in any study. Could range from rare to common, especially among patients with IgG1 deficiency (impaired sequential switching) or villous atrophy (reduced pIgR transport).
overlooked_populations.why_missed: Guidelines use serum total IgA as the sole gatekeeper for trusting IgA-based serology. Normal serum IgA → algorithm declares IgA-tTG2 'valid' → negative result interpreted as 'true negative'. No guideline checks secretory IgA or any mucosal IgA proxy. The assumption that serum IgA reflects mucosal IgA has never been validated in a celiac cohort.
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: Measure fecal secretory IgA in seronegative patients with suspected CD before concluding negative IgA-tTG2 is a true negative. If secretory IgA is low or unquantifiable despite normal serum IgA, IgA-based serology cannot be trusted and biopsy should proceed regardless of negative serology. Research priority: measure fecal sIgA in a large celiac cohort stratified by serostatus to determine prevalence of this dissociation.

diagnostic_step_sensitivity.step_name: Combined celiac serology (IgA-tTG2 + DGP-IgG) in DQ8-only patient with IgG1 deficiency
diagnostic_step_sensitivity.reported_sensitivity: 93-98% (guidelines, unstratified by HLA or Ig subclass)
diagnostic_step_sensitivity.adjusted_sensitivity: Estimated <30% for patients with DQ8 + IgG1 deficiency + Marsh 3A, based on multiplicative model: ~50% (DQ8 T-cell help deficit) × ~50% (IgG1 sequential switching impairment for IgA; direct IgG1 reduction for DGP-IgG) × tissue sequestration margin
diagnostic_step_sensitivity.false_negative_rate: Estimated >70% for this specific patient subgroup
key_limitations: No direct measurement of serological sensitivity stratified by HLA-DQ subtype exists
No study has measured anti-DGP IgG subclass distribution
DGP peptide may have zero sensitivity for DQ8-α-I-driven antibodies
IgG1 deficiency simultaneously impairs IgA production (via sequential switching) AND IgG detection (via subclass depletion)
Serum total IgA is used to validate IgA-based serology but does not reflect mucosal IgA production capacity (Model D)
Fecal secretory IgA has never been measured in any celiac diagnostic validation study
Multiplicative model is novel synthesis — not yet empirically validated as integrated framework
Tissue TG2 sequestration magnitude not quantified in vivo

contradictory_studies.citation: Zhou et al. 2022 — Claimed anti-DGP B-cell epitope recognition is HLA-independent
contradictory_studies.finding: QPEQPFP identified as dominant B-cell epitope 'irrespective of HLA-DQ allotype'
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Our Model B hypothesis that DQ8 drives different antibody specificities. However, DQ8-only patients were a tiny fraction of the study population, and magnitude of response by genotype was not separately analyzed — the claim of HLA-independence was not rigorously tested for DQ8.

contradictory_studies.citation: Simon-Vecsei et al. 2012 — Anti-tTG2 antibodies converge on single conformational epitope
contradictory_studies.finding: Celiac anti-tTG2 antibodies target a conserved conformational epitope (Glu153/Glu154, Arg19) that is disease-specific and structural
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Hypothesis that DQ8 patients produce qualitatively different anti-tTG2 antibodies. If the tTG2 epitope is structural and HLA-independent, the IgA-tTG2 test should work equally well across genotypes — making Model B more applicable to DGP than tTG2 assays.

contradictory_studies.citation: Iversen et al. 2019 — T-B cell collaboration drives autoantibody epitope bias
contradictory_studies.finding: Efficient T-B collaboration selects for B cells targeting N-terminal tTG2 epitopes through hapten-carrier mechanism, and the selected epitopes depend on which gluten peptides the T cells recognize
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Simon-Vecsei's single-epitope convergence — Iversen shows four distinct conformational epitope groups whose relative dominance may vary by HLA context, leaving room for DQ8-specific differences in anti-tTG2 epitope hierarchy

contradictory_studies.citation: Shimada et al. 1999 — pIgR knockout increases serum IgA
contradictory_studies.finding: pIgR-deficient mice show dramatically increased serum IgA and decreased fecal IgA
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Model C's compartmentalization hypothesis — if Marsh 3A reduces pIgR expression, serum IgA should INCREASE, not decrease. This paradox favors Model A (reduced production) over Model C (compartmentalization) as the primary mechanism.

research_gaps.gap: No DQ8-only celiac cohort has been specifically studied for antibody characteristics (mean titers, IgG subclass distribution, DGP peptide cross-reactivity, anti-tTG2 epitope hierarchy)
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Cross-sectional study comparing DQ8-only (n≥50) vs DQ2.5 (n≥100) celiac patients: measure (a) mean antibody titers for all standard tests, (b) anti-DGP IgG subclass distribution, (c) reactivity with DQ8-derived peptides (EGSFQPSQE-based DGP), (d) anti-tTG2 epitope mapping by competition ELISA

research_gaps.gap: Anti-DGP IgG subclass distribution has never been measured in any celiac cohort
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Measure IgG1, IgG2, IgG3, IgG4 anti-DGP antibodies by subclass-specific ELISA in diagnosed celiac patients (n≥200) stratified by HLA genotype. If IgG1-dominant, this explains why IgG1-deficient patients test negative on DGP-IgG.

research_gaps.gap: No study has tested seronegative CD patients with DQ8-specific deamidated gliadin peptides
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Generate synthetic peptides from DQ8-α-I (EGSFQPSQE) and DQ8-γ-I (EQPQQPFPE) epitopes, deamidate appropriately, and test seronegative DQ8 celiac patients by ELISA. Positive results would prove epitope mismatch as a cause of seronegativity.

research_gaps.gap: IgG1 subclass deficiency prevalence in celiac disease populations is unknown
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Measure IgG subclasses in large celiac cohort (n≥500) stratified by serology status (seropositive, low-positive, seronegative) and HLA genotype. Test whether IgG1 deficiency is enriched in seronegative CD.

research_gaps.gap: Mucosal TG2-IgA deposit intensity has never been quantified specifically in DQ8-only celiac patients
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Quantitative immunofluorescence of TG2-IgA deposits in DQ8-only vs DQ2.5 celiac biopsies with concurrent serum serology. If deposits are weaker in DQ8, this confirms reduced production (Model A); if equal, it supports compartmentalization (Model C).

research_gaps.gap: Siniscalco 2025 sequential class-switching pathway has not been examined in celiac disease-specific B cells
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Single-cell BCR sequencing of intestinal anti-tTG2 IgA plasma cells: look for Sγ1 switch region remnants in Sμ-Sα junctions, confirming IgG1 intermediate. Compare frequency of sequential vs direct switching in celiac vs non-celiac IgA plasma cells.

research_gaps.gap: No study distinguishes 'completely undetectable' (<1 U/mL) from 'low positive below cutoff' seronegative populations
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Retrospective analysis of seronegative CD cohorts reporting absolute titer values. Stratify by <1, 1-cutoff, and compare: HLA genotype distribution, IgG subclass levels, Marsh grade, mucosal deposit intensity, clinical phenotype.

research_gaps.gap: Tissue TG2 antibody-binding capacity has never been quantitatively modeled in vivo
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Quantitative immunohistochemistry of total tissue TG2 protein vs TG2-bound IgA in celiac biopsies, calculating saturation fraction. If tissue TG2 is far in excess of bound IgA, the antigen sink hypothesis is plausible; if nearly saturated, it is not.

research_gaps.gap: Prevalence of normal serum IgA with depleted fecal secretory IgA has never been studied in any population, let alone in celiac disease
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Measure paired serum total IgA and fecal secretory IgA in: (a) large celiac cohort stratified by serostatus (seropositive, low-positive, seronegative), (b) healthy controls, (c) symptomatic patients under celiac investigation. Determine prevalence of dissociation (normal serum, low/unquantifiable secretory). Correlate with IgG1 subclass levels to test whether IgG1 deficiency predicts the dissociation via impaired sequential switching.

differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: Villous atrophy, increased IELs, IgG subclass deficiency. CVID enteropathy can mimic Marsh 3A. Both can present with low immunoglobulins and seronegative enteropathy.
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: CVID typically has low total IgG (<5 g/L) and/or low IgA (<0.07 g/L), impaired vaccine responses, recurrent infections. Reference patient has normal total IgG and normal IgA, with only isolated IgG1 deficiency — not typical CVID. However, overlap exists and CVID should be excluded.

differential_diagnoses_relevant.condition: Selective IgG1 deficiency as primary immunodeficiency (not secondary to CD)
differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: Can cause enteropathy independently of celiac disease through impaired mucosal immunity. Could present with villous atrophy and negative serology.
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: If IgG1 deficiency is the primary problem, GFD would not improve histology. GFD response is the key distinguishing feature. However, both conditions could coexist, with IgG1 deficiency exacerbating celiac seronegativity.

differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: Villous atrophy, can be seronegative for celiac markers. May have anti-enterocyte or anti-goblet cell antibodies.
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: Does not respond to GFD. Anti-enterocyte antibodies if present. May have more diffuse GI involvement beyond duodenum.

recommendations.recommendation: IgG subclass testing (IgG1, IgG2, IgG3, IgG4) should be added to celiac workup in any patient with negative IgA-tTG2 AND negative DGP-IgG, before concluding serology is 'normal negative'
recommendations.evidence_basis: IgG1 dominates anti-tTG IgG (Comerford 2015) and anti-gliadin IgG (Uhde 2020). IgG1 deficiency simultaneously impairs IgG-based backup tests AND mucosal IgA production via sequential class switching (Siniscalco 2025). Without IgG subclass data, clinicians cannot determine if negative IgG results are biologically meaningful.

recommendations.recommendation: Develop and validate HLA-stratified DGP test panels including DQ8-derived peptides (based on DQ8-α-I and DQ8-γ-I epitopes)
recommendations.evidence_basis: Current DGP peptide (PLQPEQPFP) has zero sequence homology with immunodominant DQ8-α-I epitope (EGSFQPSQE). DQ2.2-specific epitopes exist (Bodd 2012). HLA-specific serological testing is mechanistically justified but has never been developed.

recommendations.recommendation: Clinical guidelines should distinguish 'completely undetectable' serology (<1 U/mL all tests) from 'low positive below cutoff' as potentially different clinical entities requiring different diagnostic approaches
recommendations.evidence_basis: Multiplicative model predicts these populations have different mechanisms: complete undetectability suggests concurrent production failure (multiple mechanisms), while near-threshold values suggest single partial reduction. Different mechanisms require different diagnostic interventions.

recommendations.recommendation: Mucosal TG2-IgA immunofluorescence on frozen biopsies should be recommended as standard diagnostic step for any patient with suspected seronegative CD, not reserved as a research tool
recommendations.evidence_basis: 100% sensitivity in adult SNCD (Salmi 2006). When serology fails due to multiplicative mechanisms, mucosal deposits are the only remaining antibody-based diagnostic. The pIgR paradox confirms some antibody must still be produced locally even when serum is undetectable.

recommendations.recommendation: Future celiac antibody studies MUST report results stratified by HLA-DQ subtype (DQ2.5, DQ2.2, DQ8, other) and measure IgG subclass levels
recommendations.evidence_basis: Without HLA stratification, DQ8-specific sensitivity cannot be calculated. Without IgG subclass data, a defined immunodeficient population is invisible. Current unstratified reporting perpetuates the assumption of uniform test performance.

recommendations.recommendation: Fecal secretory IgA should be measured in any patient with negative IgA-tTG2 and normal serum total IgA before concluding that IgA-based serology is reliable. If secretory IgA is low or unquantifiable, the negative IgA-tTG2 cannot be interpreted as a true negative, and biopsy should proceed regardless.
recommendations.evidence_basis: Serum IgA and secretory IgA are independently regulated (O'Mahony 1991). Anti-tTG2 IgA originates in intestinal mucosa (Di Niro 2012), not blood. The reference patient proves that normal serum IgA can coexist with unquantifiable fecal secretory IgA. Current guidelines use serum IgA as sole proxy for mucosal IgA capacity — this assumption has never been validated and is demonstrably false in at least one confirmed case.

recommendations.recommendation: A simple 3-test panel — (1) IgG subclass levels, (2) fecal secretory IgA, (3) full HLA-DQ allele typing — should be considered for any patient with negative celiac serology and clinical suspicion. This panel maps to the two mechanistic hubs underlying all four models: IgG1 identifies risk for Models A+D, HLA-DQ identifies risk for Models A+B, and secretory IgA directly tests Model D. A fourth test — mucosal TG2-IgA immunofluorescence — confirms Model C.
recommendations.evidence_basis: The four models of complete seronegativity are interconnected through two hubs (IgG1 deficiency → A+D; DQ8 genotype → A+B). Three simple, available tests can identify patients at risk for all four failure modes. None of these tests are in any current diagnostic guideline. Prospective validation in a seronegative CD cohort would determine clinical utility.

recommendations.recommendation: For any patient matching this risk profile (DQ8, mild IgG1 deficiency, suspected seronegative CD): intestinal TG2-IgA immunofluorescence on frozen duodenal biopsies is the highest-yield next diagnostic test, predicted to be positive by the convergent model
recommendations.evidence_basis: The pIgR paradox and Hietikko 2018 data confirm that mucosal antibody production occurs even when serum is undetectable. The convergent model predicts deposits should be present (production is reduced but not zero), potentially with lower intensity than DQ2.5 patients.

pooled_estimates.estimated_multiplicative_reduction_DQ8_p: <2% of DQ2.5 baseline, below detection threshold

meta_analysis_summary.heterogeneity_notes: This is an integrative synthesis rather than a traditional meta-analysis. The four models draw from different research domains (structural immunology, B-cell biology, mucosal immunology, mucosal transport physiology) that have never been connected in published literature. Key quantitative estimates (50-70% reduction per mechanism) are extrapolated from indirect evidence rather than directly measured in DQ8-only cohorts. The pIgR paradox provides internal consistency check favoring Model A over Model C. Model D (serum IgA ≠ mucosal IgA) is directly demonstrated by patient data but population prevalence of this dissociation is unknown. The four models organize around two mechanistic hubs (IgG1 → A+D; DQ8 → A+B) rather than being independent, suggesting a compact diagnostic panel could identify at-risk patients. The most critical limitation is that no single study has simultaneously examined HLA genotype, IgG subclass levels, fecal secretory IgA, and mucosal deposit characteristics in the same seronegative CD cohort.
